data.title: THE SAMOAN CRISIS.
data.meta_description: The Rev. Joseph King, of the London Missionary Society, who for many years was resident in Samoa, states to-night that he cannot understand why the intention of the ...
data.text:
Rev. Joseph King, of the London

Missionary Society, who for many years was

resident in Samoa, states to-night that he

cannot understand why the intention of the

British Consul to support with force the

decision of the Chief Justice was not carried

out. It was remarkable to his mind

that the German Consul should have led

the rebels, and he cannot understand, how

it was that Herr von Billow had gone

so far if he had not had very decided

instructions from his Government. The

action of Germany threw a very significant

light on the German conduct in Ihn'group,

despite the late disavowal of that nation

that it had any sinister motives in respect

to it. For Germany to throw down the

gauntlet as she had done was inexplicable.

Mr. King further states that he has had

a personal experience (of Mataafa, who, he

says, is very sagacious, has wonderful

force of character, and is altogether a very

fine personality. Farm, on the other hand,

is a youth of 18, and has to win his name.

Mr. King mentions that for a man to be

King of Samoa he must be possessed of

live distinct titles and that it is over this

particular matter that the whole of the

dispute as to the succession hinges. '
